sub_topic: Mass transfer and diffusion in fluids
message_1: A container has two compartments separated by a semi-permeable membrane. The left compartment contains water with a concentration of salt at 10 g/L while the right compartment has pure water. The membrane has a permeability of 0.005 cm/s and a surface area of 50 cm². Calculate the rate of mass transfer of salt through the membrane from left to the right compartment.
message_2:
To calculate the rate of mass transfer of salt through the membrane, we can use Fick's first law of diffusion:

J = -P * A * (dc/dx)

where J is the rate of mass transfer (g/s), P is the permeability of the membrane (cm/s), A is the surface area of the membrane (cm²), and (dc/dx) is the concentration gradient of salt across the membrane (g/cm³).

First, we need to convert the concentration of salt from g/L to g/cm³:

10 g/L * (1 L / 1000 cm³) = 0.01 g/cm³

Since the right compartment has pure water, the concentration of salt in the right compartment is 0 g/cm³. The concentration gradient (dc/dx) can be calculated as the difference in concentration divided by the distance between the compartments. In this case, we can assume that the distance between the compartments is very small compared to the concentration difference, so the concentration gradient can be approximated as:

(dc/dx) ≈ (0.01 g/cm³ - 0 g/cm³) / small distance ≈ 0.01 g/cm³

Now, we can plug the values into Fick's first law of diffusion:

J = -P * A * (dc/dx)
J = -(-0.005 cm/s) * (50 cm²) * (0.01 g/cm³)
J = 0.005 * 50 * 0.01
J = 0.0025 g/s

The rate of mass transfer of salt through the membrane from the left to the right compartment is approximately 0.0025 g/s.
